## Re:[31] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 27, 2010, 01:17:46 PM  
---  
It is the tendancy of our nature that we complicate things by not only our own  
analysis but also analysis of analyses itself.   
Who am I is simply holding on to the 'I'. All the analysis are to be given  
absolutely no importance at all. one need not even learn all these  
intricacies. After all what is the real objective? is not to hold on to the  
'I'? its like, we forget the main dishes served in an plantain leaf and  
showing more interest in the "echils" \- food spilt down from our mouth.   
These are just tools for 'I' so that it can simply continue in the garb of  
spiritual enquiry and enjoy its existence. It does not at akk matter if  
awareness is watching awareness or awareness is not watching awareness,  
whether Ramana's teachings are same as Michal James or different, whether  
Bhakti yoga is same as Jnana Yoga or different. Whether my point is accepted  
here or rejected. whether the discussions is helping or not.   
'I' \- just hold on to it, everything else is play and only play: Merry-  
Go-Round   
Self Enquiry is like the passive observer. A classic example which Shankara  
Bhagavatpadal has given is that of the bird Dove which lays eggs and carefully  
guards it everyday and accumulates food for it from various places and when  
the eggs are going to hatch, one day the crow comes pushes the eggs down from  
the nest and eats all the eggs and just born dove. The dove, which comes there  
just sees all this without reaction. It just remains.   
Such should be our enquiry.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

Here is the classic pic taken from the famous movie Adi Shankaracharya. Its  
one of the best examples as to how our enquiry has to be carried on: Crow and dove.Crow is the doer, the active one.The dove is the passive  
observer, the atman(inner self) - our attention should be always focussed only  
on this.   
instead of focusing our attention on the 'I', if the Dove begins to fight with  
the crow, it is only going to cause damage and loss of peace. Just remaining  
indifferent to what is happening, remaining in the world, carrying out our  
duties, we should remain like the Dove with our attention focused on the Self  
till our Prarabhha karma is dissolved.

## Re:[34] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Subramanian.R       Date: June 28, 2010, 06:16:55 AM  
---  
Dear viswanathan   
I agree with your detailed clarfifcations on the points of Michael   
Langford 'Awareness Watching Awareness'. The problems in   
any translation of the original work are that one has to compromise   
with some loss of beauty and cadence. A friend of mine, long time   
back, went to study Russian, to read Leo Tolstoy's War and Peace   
in original. But most of us cannot do that way. Why? Even Tamizhians today  
cannot properly read and understand classical   
Tamizh works like Bhagavan's ULLadu Narpadu. The untranslatatbility of Tamizh  
is quite high. In Tamizh, one often goes even without a verb. Nan Yaar means  
only "I Who" and not   
"Who am I?" Hence many problems have to be confronted by the   
translators. So long as Langford clarifies Watching means Being,   
then, as I already wrote, there is no problem. Even in Sanskrit,   
sometimes the word Darshan means not seeing but being. Siva darshan sometimes  
means Being Siva or Being in Sivam.   
As regards methods, again since every marga leads one ultimately to the one  
marga of self attention, there is no quarrel, in that sense.   
I also refer to Michael James as you have mentioned. He is the guy who read  
and mastered Tamizh while simultaneously venturing understanding and  
practicing Bhagavan Ramana's methods. Hence his books and translations are  
really of a higher order. In his   
Happiness and the Art of Being, he refers to ULLadu Narpadu   
verses and he always gives in italics the Tamizh word or phrases and again and  
again use many ways to describe the purport.   
Arunachala Siva.

Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 28, 2010, 07:19:36 AM  
---  
Dear I,   
Quote from: viswanathan on June 28, 2010, 03:16:39 AM  
 I agree with your comments as above.When we know that who am I is simply holding on to the "I", why so many posts in this forum on various headings on various topics?. **Bhagavan has given his first teaching "Naan Yar' crystal clear without any room for doubt and still do we require endless discussions on his teachings ?** **It is enough if only Bhagavan 's teachings alone are published in this site as being done by Sri Subramanian and Mr.Prasanth (Both of them are doing great service) and there are sufficient material for them to publish more of Bhagaan's works for many years**.This will help members who have not so far gone thro his books and for the one who has already gone through, it will help to refresh.Few years back, Swami Chinmayananda was invited to a Ramana function and was asked to deliver his talk on Bhagavan Ramana.He did not deliver lecture and instead sat in silence forsome time and at the end told the audience that this is what bhagavan's teaching. **Bhagavan says that Silence is ever speaking and it is interrupted by speaking.Are we following his teachings?**  
You are absolutely correct. The best course is to simply maintain silence. I  
have always found the tamizh works of Ramana more clearer than any of the  
other languages, it may be because it is my mother tongue, but I did not know  
how to read or write tamizh, but due to Bhagavan's grace, I am learning to  
read and write tamizh now atleast I am able to read it slowly though.   
Personally, I feel, Bhagavan's teachings are to be discussed within the Self  
alone, in the course of enquiry itself and not outside. One has to taste the  
tea himself to know its taste, no matter what elaboration anybody gives, is  
going to be of no avail.   
It is due to the Vasana of finding out answers to our questions that breeds  
questions and endless discussions. Bhagavans says, we need not know any  
answers at all. We fail to recognise the very presence of Bhagavan Ramana, if  
he is not there physically, does it mean that he is not going to clear our  
questions within? its because of this wrong notion, that we begin to discuss  
our issues or questions and it leads to analyses over analyses. What we need  
is a strong belief or Faith or Shraddha that Bhagavan will clear all doubts  
Himself and I need not ask anybody and that He himself will reveal it to me in  
any way, maybe an unknown person would come and say something in some other  
context, or through some incidents. We just need to remain alive and keep the  
enquiry always going. Like how Dhathathreya had 24 Gurus, most of them being  
animals, in a similar way, Bhagavan will bestow on us the clarity in some way  
or the other.   
To ask doubts and discussing it is going outwards. We have to remain within  
our self - holding on just to 'I' alone.   
In Talks: 253: Bhagavan has said The illiterates are certainly better off than the  
literates whose egos are not destroyed by the quest of the self.   
355: "Illiteracy is ignorance: education is learned ignorance. Both of them  
are ignorant of their true aim; whereas a sage is not ignorant because there  
is no aim for him."   
D.: Mind itself is very subtle and is also the same as the Atman.   
How shall we know the nature of the mind? You have said that all   
supports are useless. What should be our stand then?   
M.: Where does your mind stand?   
D.: Where does it stand?   
M.: Ask the mind itself.   
D.: I ask you now. Should we concentrate on mind then?   
M.: Um!   
D.: But what is the nature of the mind? It is formless. The problem   
is perplexing.   
M.: Why are you perplexed?   
D.: The sastras want us to concentrate and I cannot do so.   
M.: Through what sastras have we known our existence?   
D.: It is a matter of experience. But I want to concentrate.   
M.: Be free from thoughts. Do not hold on to anything. They do not   
hold you. Be yourself.   
D.: I do not yet understand as to where I take my stand and concentrate.   
Can I meditate on my mind?   
M.: Whose mind?   
D.: My own mind?   
M.: Who are you? The question now resolves itself all right.   
(All retired for lunch. The visitor returned at 2-30 p.m. and pursued   
the same question.)   
He said: Maharshi advises the seeker to get rid of thoughts. On what   
should I concentrate the mind after all the thoughts are expelled? I   
do not see where I stand then and on what I should concentrate.   
M.: For whom is the concentration?   
D.: For the mind.   
M.: Then concentrate the mind.   
D.: On what?   
M.: Answer the question yourself. What is the mind? Why should   
you concentrate?   
D.: I do not know what the mind is. I ask Maharshi.   
M.: Maharshi does not seek to know the mind. The questioner must   
question the mind itself as to what it is.   
 **D.: Maharshi advises that the mind should be divested of thoughts.   
M.: This is itself a thought.**   
D.: When all thoughts disappear what remains over?   
M.: Is the mind different from thoughts?   
 **D.: No. The mind is made up of thoughts. My point is this: When all   
thoughts are got rid of, how shall I concentrate the mind?   
M.: Is not this also a thought?**   
D.: Yes, but I am advised to concentrate.   
M.: Why should you concentrate? Why should you not allow your   
thoughts free play?   
D.: The sastras say that the thoughts, thus playing free, lead us astray,   
that is, to unreal and changeful things.   
M.: So then, you want not to be led to unreal and changeful things. Your   
thoughts are unreal and changeful. You want to hold the Reality. That   
is exactly what I say. The thoughts are unreal. Get rid of them.   
 **D.: I understand now. Yet there is a doubt. Not a trice can you remain   
inactive. How shall I be able to rid myself of thoughts?   
M.: The same Gita says: Although all actions take place, I am not the doer.   
It is like the sun towards the world activities. The Self always remains   
actionless, whereas thoughts arise and subside. The Self is Perfection; it   
is immutable; the mind is limited and changeful. You need only to cast   
off your limitations. Your perfection thus stands revealed.**   
D.: Grace is necessary for it.   
 _ **M.: Grace is ever present. All that is necessary is that you surrender to  
It.**_   
D.: I surrender and pray that even if I go wrong I may be forcibly   
drawn to it.   
 **M.: Is this surrender? Surrender to be complete must be   
unquestioning.**   
D.: Yes, I surrender. You say I must dive into the ocean of the Self   
like a pearl-diver into the sea.   
M.: Because you are now thinking that you are out of the ocean of   
Consciousness.   
D.: I practise pranayama. It generates heat in the body. What should   
I do?   
M.: The heat will pass away when the mind gains calm   
D.: That is true but most difficult.   
 **M.: This is again a thought which is an obstacle.  
Salutations to Sri Ramana

The point is : mind cannot be killed, coz its never alive to be killed.   
like the snake on a rope. should the snake be killed?   
i am awareness, right now -- there is no choice here.   
and as awareness, i "CANNOT" get sad, happy or anything else. AS AWareness, i  
a Every STillness.   
so its not "Be Still" \-- u R STILLNESS. .. no choice here!   
so when someone says "I WILL BE STILL" thats foolish. As Awareness there is no  
choice. One is STILLNESS ITSELF.   
AS mind, one cannot remain still... coz mind by nature is unreal. mind cannot  
become SAT.   
So, here is the problem. People want the mind to be Still... body to stop  
growing!! how is it ever possible.   
body by its nature has to grow old. mind by its nature has to change. Self  
cannot Change.   
This is the essence.   
Swami Suddhananda gives a nice example: Someone was asked "What is ur age", he  
said "30". "But u said the same thing 10 years ago", asked another who was  
present there. "That is right, i tell the truth and truth cannot change", was  
his reply!   
what kind of truth is that??   
The attempt to stop the mirage like world from appearing is also a mistake.  
coz it shall continue as long as one's prarabdha is there unfinished. no one  
can stop it.   
Love!   
Silence

## Re:[30] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: viswanathan         Date: June 27, 2010, 11:51:16 AM  
---  
Dear Devotees,   
 I would like to share some of my views on various comments by forum members. Members comments are given in bold and my comments are in italics.   
1\. AWA is not Self enquiry since the moment the word watching is used, then  
the   
 subject object relation ship comes into picture and hence it cannot be the state of   
 BEING..Also how can awareness be watched?   
 _  
Comments: Mr. Michael Langford has mentioned that Awareness Watching  
Awareness is Awareness Being Awareness and he also says that because of long  
ancient habit of looking outwards towards people places and things, the word  
watching is used in practice instructions. Also he says that that way we take  
that same habit of watching people, places and things and we shut our eyes and  
turn it inwards. That is why the word watching is used. **Mr.Michael Langford  
says that what is real is awareness watching awareness, looking inward. What  
is unreal is looking outward towards the world of people places and things.  
Hence AWA is in line with Bjhagavans Self Enquiry   
**There are some comments in the forum that how can awareness be watched? If  
the word watching is inappropriate, then a doubt arises in mind how the  
word enquiry is appropriate in Self enquiry. When the word enquiry is used  
then doubt arises about who should enquire and whether self can be enquired  
and if self can be enquired then there must be enquirer similar to watcher in  
the word watching. All these doubts do not arise if tamil word SUMMA IRU is  
used to denote self enquiry**. Bhagavan ramana maharishi has instructed my  
mother around 80 years ago when she was a child that she should read  
Bhagavans works in the same language in which it was originally composed.I  
remember to have read some where that Bhagavan has given similar  
instructions to Annamalai Swami. Bhagavan has composed his great works such  
as   
 Nan Yar, Upadesa Undiar, Ulladhu Naarpathu,Arunachala Akshara mana malai etc  
in Tamil and when it is translated in other languages, it does not convey the  
same meaning as in tamil.. **In this context, I would like members to go  
through the commentary in English on Nan Yar by Mr.Michel James where in he  
uses the same original tamil words in many places in his commentary to  
ensure that the meaning is not distorted.**_   
[/b]   
2.As per AWA, it should be done on certain hours.   
 _Comments:Mr Michael Langford says that spend as many hours per day  
practicing as you can. **If you only practice awareness watching awareness for  
30 minutes per day and spend the other 23 and a half hours looking outward,  
you will not progress very quickly. If you want rapid results, then drop your  
unnecessary activities to free up time so you can practice for many hours per  
day, everyday. Maybe once per week on one of your days off from work you can  
devote the whole day to just practicing awareness watching awareness. Again  
this is in line with Bhagavans teachings that vichara should be done  
throughout the entire waking state   
**_ [/b]   
3.As per AWA, one should practice with eyes closed.   
 _Comments:To a question put to Bhagavan whether eyes should be open or not  
like this Bhagaan answers thus   
A: It may be done either way. The point is that the mind must be introverted  
and kept active in its pursuit. Sometimes it happens that when the eyes are  
closed the latent thoughts rush forth with great vigour. It may also be  
difficult to introvert the mind with the eyes open. It requires strength of  
mind to do so. The mind is contaminated when it takes in objects. Otherwise,  
it is pure. The main factor in dhyana is to keep the mind active in its own  
pursuit without taking in external impressions or thinking of other matters.   
 **From the very first sentence in Bhagavan s answer, it is evident that it  
may be done either way.**   
_   
4.As per AWA,ten methods are suggested and how can there be 10 methods since  
there is only one method, self attention or Summa irutthal. Being still.   
 _Comments: In Hinduism, four margas(paths) are prescribed for realization  
and devotees can follow any marga to reach the goal of Self realization. In  
Guru Ramana Mr.Cohen, quotes Bhagavan and says that the ultimate goal is  
realize the self and the paths are left to individuals. In fact, Bhagavan has  
told that Bakthi and Jnana are one and the same. In this context, I would like  
to quote an explanation given by late Paramacharya of Kanchi Mutt Sri  
Chandrasekara Saraswathi Swamigal. A devotee had a genuine doubt and asked  
Paramacharya why Paramacharya is confined to pujas and rituals and does not  
perform siddhis(miracles) like Sri. Sathya Sai Baba.. Paramacharya replied  
that the goal of his and Sri.Sathya Sa Baba are one and the same ie to bring  
everybody in to divinity and only difference is that they adopt different  
techniques like marketing people adopt different techniques to sell the goods.   
Bhagvan has given all the spiritual instructions very crystal clear and in  
simple language. In spite of that, during his life time, we can find devotees  
going on questioning about self enquiry again and again and this is evident  
if we go through the bookTalks wherein similar questions on self enquiry  
are repeated at number of places by different devotees. These devotees who put  
questions to hagavan are not ordinary layman but intellectuals and highly  
learned. **In order to cater to needs of people with different caliber,  
Micheal has given different methods and he is not suggested to follow all  
methods. It is left to individuals to follow the method which suits him  
best.This is in line with Bhagavan suggesting two methods ie doing sadhana  
with closed eyes and with open eyes. Which ever suits a devotee, he can follow  
it. Ultimately, the goal is to turn our attention inwards to the subject from  
objects.**   
 **All 10 methods suggested by Mr.Michael boils down to turning the  
attention inwards only and nothing else. Once a devotee becomes proficient in  
practice, he can practice sadhana eyes closed/open, one hour a day to 24  
hours a day,walking/sitting /laying/at rest room/ brushing his teeth. Only  
time he cannot do is while at sleep and when he is actively engaged in any  
work.When he is engaged in any serious activity, he automatically goes into  
meditation since his full attention is on that activity and there no  
thoughts**.   
**To conclude, I am fully convinced by Bhagavans teaching that at some  
point of time, we should forget what we have learned, stop reading books and  
turn our attention inwards. By mere reading various scriptures and endless  
discussion does not lead to realization unless we practice what we have  
learned.. To quote swami Sivananda of Rishikesh, an ounce of practice is  
better than tons of reading. In Sanskrit, it is known as Sravanam, mananam and  
Nithidyasanam and in Tirukkural, Tiruvallur says Karka Kashadara  
Karka.karrapin Nirka Thaga when means read and understand well and then  
practice what you have learnt. Do we[/b_**]?   
[/i]

## Re:[31] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 27, 2010, 01:17:46 PM  
---  
It is the tendancy of our nature that we complicate things by not only our own  
analysis but also analysis of analyses itself.   
Who am I is simply holding on to the 'I'. All the analysis are to be given  
absolutely no importance at all. one need not even learn all these  
intricacies. After all what is the real objective? is not to hold on to the  
'I'? its like, we forget the main dishes served in an plantain leaf and  
showing more interest in the "echils" \- food spilt down from our mouth.   
These are just tools for 'I' so that it can simply continue in the garb of  
spiritual enquiry and enjoy its existence. It does not at akk matter if  
awareness is watching awareness or awareness is not watching awareness,  
whether Ramana's teachings are same as Michal James or different, whether  
Bhakti yoga is same as Jnana Yoga or different. Whether my point is accepted  
here or rejected. whether the discussions is helping or not.   
'I' \- just hold on to it, everything else is play and only play: Merry-  
Go-Round   
Self Enquiry is like the passive observer. A classic example which Shankara  
Bhagavatpadal has given is that of the bird Dove which lays eggs and carefully  
guards it everyday and accumulates food for it from various places and when  
the eggs are going to hatch, one day the crow comes pushes the eggs down from  
the nest and eats all the eggs and just born dove. The dove, which comes there  
just sees all this without reaction. It just remains.   
Such should be our enquiry.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

## Re:[34] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Subramanian.R       Date: June 28, 2010, 06:16:55 AM  
---  
Dear viswanathan   
I agree with your detailed clarfifcations on the points of Michael   
Langford 'Awareness Watching Awareness'. The problems in   
any translation of the original work are that one has to compromise   
with some loss of beauty and cadence. A friend of mine, long time   
back, went to study Russian, to read Leo Tolstoy's War and Peace   
in original. But most of us cannot do that way. Why? Even Tamizhians today  
cannot properly read and understand classical   
Tamizh works like Bhagavan's ULLadu Narpadu. The untranslatatbility of Tamizh  
is quite high. In Tamizh, one often goes even without a verb. Nan Yaar means  
only "I Who" and not   
"Who am I?" Hence many problems have to be confronted by the   
translators. So long as Langford clarifies Watching means Being,   
then, as I already wrote, there is no problem. Even in Sanskrit,   
sometimes the word Darshan means not seeing but being. Siva darshan sometimes  
means Being Siva or Being in Sivam.   
As regards methods, again since every marga leads one ultimately to the one  
marga of self attention, there is no quarrel, in that sense.   
I also refer to Michael James as you have mentioned. He is the guy who read  
and mastered Tamizh while simultaneously venturing understanding and  
practicing Bhagavan Ramana's methods. Hence his books and translations are  
really of a higher order. In his   
Happiness and the Art of Being, he refers to ULLadu Narpadu   
verses and he always gives in italics the Tamizh word or phrases and again and  
again use many ways to describe the purport.   
Arunachala Siva.

## Re:[36] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 28, 2010, 07:19:36 AM  
---  
Dear I,   
Quote from: viswanathan on June 28, 2010, 03:16:39 AM  
 I agree with your comments as above.When we know that who am I is simply holding on to the "I", why so many posts in this forum on various headings on various topics?. **Bhagavan has given his first teaching "Naan Yar' crystal clear without any room for doubt and still do we require endless discussions on his teachings ?** **It is enough if only Bhagavan 's teachings alone are published in this site as being done by Sri Subramanian and Mr.Prasanth (Both of them are doing great service) and there are sufficient material for them to publish more of Bhagaan's works for many years**.This will help members who have not so far gone thro his books and for the one who has already gone through, it will help to refresh.Few years back, Swami Chinmayananda was invited to a Ramana function and was asked to deliver his talk on Bhagavan Ramana.He did not deliver lecture and instead sat in silence forsome time and at the end told the audience that this is what bhagavan's teaching. **Bhagavan says that Silence is ever speaking and it is interrupted by speaking.Are we following his teachings?**  
You are absolutely correct. The best course is to simply maintain silence. I  
have always found the tamizh works of Ramana more clearer than any of the  
other languages, it may be because it is my mother tongue, but I did not know  
how to read or write tamizh, but due to Bhagavan's grace, I am learning to  
read and write tamizh now atleast I am able to read it slowly though.   
Personally, I feel, Bhagavan's teachings are to be discussed within the Self  
alone, in the course of enquiry itself and not outside. One has to taste the  
tea himself to know its taste, no matter what elaboration anybody gives, is  
going to be of no avail.   
It is due to the Vasana of finding out answers to our questions that breeds  
questions and endless discussions. Bhagavans says, we need not know any  
answers at all. We fail to recognise the very presence of Bhagavan Ramana, if  
he is not there physically, does it mean that he is not going to clear our  
questions within? its because of this wrong notion, that we begin to discuss  
our issues or questions and it leads to analyses over analyses. What we need  
is a strong belief or Faith or Shraddha that Bhagavan will clear all doubts  
Himself and I need not ask anybody and that He himself will reveal it to me in  
any way, maybe an unknown person would come and say something in some other  
context, or through some incidents. We just need to remain alive and keep the  
enquiry always going. Like how Dhathathreya had 24 Gurus, most of them being  
animals, in a similar way, Bhagavan will bestow on us the clarity in some way  
or the other.   
To ask doubts and discussing it is going outwards. We have to remain within  
our self - holding on just to 'I' alone.   
In Talks: 253: Bhagavan has said The illiterates are certainly better off than the  
literates whose egos are not destroyed by the quest of the self.   
355: "Illiteracy is ignorance: education is learned ignorance. Both of them  
are ignorant of their true aim; whereas a sage is not ignorant because there  
is no aim for him."   
D.: Mind itself is very subtle and is also the same as the Atman.   
How shall we know the nature of the mind? You have said that all   
supports are useless. What should be our stand then?   
M.: Where does your mind stand?   
D.: Where does it stand?   
M.: Ask the mind itself.   
D.: I ask you now. Should we concentrate on mind then?   
M.: Um!   
D.: But what is the nature of the mind? It is formless. The problem   
is perplexing.   
M.: Why are you perplexed?   
D.: The sastras want us to concentrate and I cannot do so.   
M.: Through what sastras have we known our existence?   
D.: It is a matter of experience. But I want to concentrate.   
M.: Be free from thoughts. Do not hold on to anything. They do not   
hold you. Be yourself.   
D.: I do not yet understand as to where I take my stand and concentrate.   
Can I meditate on my mind?   
M.: Whose mind?   
D.: My own mind?   
M.: Who are you? The question now resolves itself all right.   
(All retired for lunch. The visitor returned at 2-30 p.m. and pursued   
the same question.)   
He said: Maharshi advises the seeker to get rid of thoughts. On what   
should I concentrate the mind after all the thoughts are expelled? I   
do not see where I stand then and on what I should concentrate.   
M.: For whom is the concentration?   
D.: For the mind.   
M.: Then concentrate the mind.   
D.: On what?   
M.: Answer the question yourself. What is the mind? Why should   
you concentrate?   
D.: I do not know what the mind is. I ask Maharshi.   
M.: Maharshi does not seek to know the mind. The questioner must   
question the mind itself as to what it is.   
 **D.: Maharshi advises that the mind should be divested of thoughts.   
M.: This is itself a thought.**   
D.: When all thoughts disappear what remains over?   
M.: Is the mind different from thoughts?   
 **D.: No. The mind is made up of thoughts. My point is this: When all   
thoughts are got rid of, how shall I concentrate the mind?   
M.: Is not this also a thought?**   
D.: Yes, but I am advised to concentrate.   
M.: Why should you concentrate? Why should you not allow your   
thoughts free play?   
D.: The sastras say that the thoughts, thus playing free, lead us astray,   
that is, to unreal and changeful things.   
M.: So then, you want not to be led to unreal and changeful things. Your   
thoughts are unreal and changeful. You want to hold the Reality. That   
is exactly what I say. The thoughts are unreal. Get rid of them.   
 **D.: I understand now. Yet there is a doubt. Not a trice can you remain   
inactive. How shall I be able to rid myself of thoughts?   
M.: The same Gita says: Although all actions take place, I am not the doer.   
It is like the sun towards the world activities. The Self always remains   
actionless, whereas thoughts arise and subside. The Self is Perfection; it   
is immutable; the mind is limited and changeful. You need only to cast   
off your limitations. Your perfection thus stands revealed.**   
D.: Grace is necessary for it.   
 _ **M.: Grace is ever present. All that is necessary is that you surrender to  
It.**_   
D.: I surrender and pray that even if I go wrong I may be forcibly   
drawn to it.   
 **M.: Is this surrender? Surrender to be complete must be   
unquestioning.**   
D.: Yes, I surrender. You say I must dive into the ocean of the Self   
like a pearl-diver into the sea.   
M.: Because you are now thinking that you are out of the ocean of   
Consciousness.   
D.: I practise pranayama. It generates heat in the body. What should   
I do?   
M.: The heat will pass away when the mind gains calm   
D.: That is true but most difficult.   
 **M.: This is again a thought which is an obstacle.  
Salutations to Sri Ramana

The point is : mind cannot be killed, coz its never alive to be killed.   
like the snake on a rope. should the snake be killed?   
i am awareness, right now -- there is no choice here.   
and as awareness, i "CANNOT" get sad, happy or anything else. AS AWareness, i  
a Every STillness.   
so its not "Be Still" \-- u R STILLNESS. .. no choice here!   
so when someone says "I WILL BE STILL" thats foolish. As Awareness there is no  
choice. One is STILLNESS ITSELF.   
AS mind, one cannot remain still... coz mind by nature is unreal. mind cannot  
become SAT.   
So, here is the problem. People want the mind to be Still... body to stop  
growing!! how is it ever possible.   
body by its nature has to grow old. mind by its nature has to change. Self  
cannot Change.   
This is the essence.   
Swami Suddhananda gives a nice example: Someone was asked "What is ur age", he  
said "30". "But u said the same thing 10 years ago", asked another who was  
present there. "That is right, i tell the truth and truth cannot change", was  
his reply!   
what kind of truth is that??   
The attempt to stop the mirage like world from appearing is also a mistake.  
coz it shall continue as long as one's prarabdha is there unfinished. no one  
can stop it.   
Love!   
Silence

is not the teaching in the movie too? is not the instruction "u r not this,

Silence  
when the sage comes on the screen and says u are not this, you are not that  
and etc... and what ever you decide to do: 1 Stop the movie,   
2 continue the movie   
3 follow the sage   
4 not listen the sage   
5 do self enquiry   
6 letting the movie continue by allowing the assitant director to decide on  
the next scenarios believing that it cannot affect me, etc...

the mind has, as options in the movie, as the director. These are "Freewill"

which is non-self. In ignorance, the character itself, is the one which has  
created the movie and various scenarios and also the sage who comes and says  
you are not this you are that is just another character in the movie created  
by the mind again to make the movie more interesting, thats all.

no more i at all, no director at all, there is no more movie anymore. Movie  
existed only for the mithya i.   
The instruction "u r not this, but that which is outside", its for mind." is  
itself just Mithya as well. It is just a story in the movie, which the i gets  
identified with whereby 'i' mistakenly takes these instruction for itself and  
begins to enquire who am i, I am the Self, I am this and I am that. these are  
all again just illusions. There is no need for self enquiry as well.   
There is no movie at all.   
Appearance is only for the 'i' mind alone. as long as the mind exists  
appearances will continue, as appearances are all the creations of the mind  
alone. Where there are no appearances and where only  
awareness/consciousness/Self alone IS, is real. _Where appearances still are_  
, the sage asks him to enquire its nature.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

## Re:[30] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: viswanathan         Date: June 27, 2010, 11:51:16 AM  
---  
Dear Devotees,   
 I would like to share some of my views on various comments by forum members. Members comments are given in bold and my comments are in italics.   
1\. AWA is not Self enquiry since the moment the word watching is used, then  
the   
 subject object relation ship comes into picture and hence it cannot be the state of   
 BEING..Also how can awareness be watched?   
 _  
Comments: Mr. Michael Langford has mentioned that Awareness Watching  
Awareness is Awareness Being Awareness and he also says that because of long  
ancient habit of looking outwards towards people places and things, the word  
watching is used in practice instructions. Also he says that that way we take  
that same habit of watching people, places and things and we shut our eyes and  
turn it inwards. That is why the word watching is used. **Mr.Michael Langford  
says that what is real is awareness watching awareness, looking inward. What  
is unreal is looking outward towards the world of people places and things.  
Hence AWA is in line with Bjhagavans Self Enquiry   
**There are some comments in the forum that how can awareness be watched? If  
the word watching is inappropriate, then a doubt arises in mind how the  
word enquiry is appropriate in Self enquiry. When the word enquiry is used  
then doubt arises about who should enquire and whether self can be enquired  
and if self can be enquired then there must be enquirer similar to watcher in  
the word watching. All these doubts do not arise if tamil word SUMMA IRU is  
used to denote self enquiry**. Bhagavan ramana maharishi has instructed my  
mother around 80 years ago when she was a child that she should read  
Bhagavans works in the same language in which it was originally composed.I  
remember to have read some where that Bhagavan has given similar  
instructions to Annamalai Swami. Bhagavan has composed his great works such  
as   
 Nan Yar, Upadesa Undiar, Ulladhu Naarpathu,Arunachala Akshara mana malai etc  
in Tamil and when it is translated in other languages, it does not convey the  
same meaning as in tamil.. **In this context, I would like members to go  
through the commentary in English on Nan Yar by Mr.Michel James where in he  
uses the same original tamil words in many places in his commentary to  
ensure that the meaning is not distorted.**_   
[/b]   
2.As per AWA, it should be done on certain hours.   
 _Comments:Mr Michael Langford says that spend as many hours per day  
practicing as you can. **If you only practice awareness watching awareness for  
30 minutes per day and spend the other 23 and a half hours looking outward,  
you will not progress very quickly. If you want rapid results, then drop your  
unnecessary activities to free up time so you can practice for many hours per  
day, everyday. Maybe once per week on one of your days off from work you can  
devote the whole day to just practicing awareness watching awareness. Again  
this is in line with Bhagavans teachings that vichara should be done  
throughout the entire waking state   
**_ [/b]   
3.As per AWA, one should practice with eyes closed.   
 _Comments:To a question put to Bhagavan whether eyes should be open or not  
like this Bhagaan answers thus   
A: It may be done either way. The point is that the mind must be introverted  
and kept active in its pursuit. Sometimes it happens that when the eyes are  
closed the latent thoughts rush forth with great vigour. It may also be  
difficult to introvert the mind with the eyes open. It requires strength of  
mind to do so. The mind is contaminated when it takes in objects. Otherwise,  
it is pure. The main factor in dhyana is to keep the mind active in its own  
pursuit without taking in external impressions or thinking of other matters.   
 **From the very first sentence in Bhagavan s answer, it is evident that it  
may be done either way.**   
_   
4.As per AWA,ten methods are suggested and how can there be 10 methods since  
there is only one method, self attention or Summa irutthal. Being still.   
 _Comments: In Hinduism, four margas(paths) are prescribed for realization  
and devotees can follow any marga to reach the goal of Self realization. In  
Guru Ramana Mr.Cohen, quotes Bhagavan and says that the ultimate goal is  
realize the self and the paths are left to individuals. In fact, Bhagavan has  
told that Bakthi and Jnana are one and the same. In this context, I would like  
to quote an explanation given by late Paramacharya of Kanchi Mutt Sri  
Chandrasekara Saraswathi Swamigal. A devotee had a genuine doubt and asked  
Paramacharya why Paramacharya is confined to pujas and rituals and does not  
perform siddhis(miracles) like Sri. Sathya Sai Baba.. Paramacharya replied  
that the goal of his and Sri.Sathya Sa Baba are one and the same ie to bring  
everybody in to divinity and only difference is that they adopt different  
techniques like marketing people adopt different techniques to sell the goods.   
Bhagvan has given all the spiritual instructions very crystal clear and in  
simple language. In spite of that, during his life time, we can find devotees  
going on questioning about self enquiry again and again and this is evident  
if we go through the bookTalks wherein similar questions on self enquiry  
are repeated at number of places by different devotees. These devotees who put  
questions to hagavan are not ordinary layman but intellectuals and highly  
learned. **In order to cater to needs of people with different caliber,  
Micheal has given different methods and he is not suggested to follow all  
methods. It is left to individuals to follow the method which suits him  
best.This is in line with Bhagavan suggesting two methods ie doing sadhana  
with closed eyes and with open eyes. Which ever suits a devotee, he can follow  
it. Ultimately, the goal is to turn our attention inwards to the subject from  
objects.**   
 **All 10 methods suggested by Mr.Michael boils down to turning the  
attention inwards only and nothing else. Once a devotee becomes proficient in  
practice, he can practice sadhana eyes closed/open, one hour a day to 24  
hours a day,walking/sitting /laying/at rest room/ brushing his teeth. Only  
time he cannot do is while at sleep and when he is actively engaged in any  
work.When he is engaged in any serious activity, he automatically goes into  
meditation since his full attention is on that activity and there no  
thoughts**.   
**To conclude, I am fully convinced by Bhagavans teaching that at some  
point of time, we should forget what we have learned, stop reading books and  
turn our attention inwards. By mere reading various scriptures and endless  
discussion does not lead to realization unless we practice what we have  
learned.. To quote swami Sivananda of Rishikesh, an ounce of practice is  
better than tons of reading. In Sanskrit, it is known as Sravanam, mananam and  
Nithidyasanam and in Tirukkural, Tiruvallur says Karka Kashadara  
Karka.karrapin Nirka Thaga when means read and understand well and then  
practice what you have learnt. Do we[/b_**]?   
[/i]

## Re:[31] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 27, 2010, 01:17:46 PM  
---  
It is the tendancy of our nature that we complicate things by not only our own  
analysis but also analysis of analyses itself.   
Who am I is simply holding on to the 'I'. All the analysis are to be given  
absolutely no importance at all. one need not even learn all these  
intricacies. After all what is the real objective? is not to hold on to the  
'I'? its like, we forget the main dishes served in an plantain leaf and  
showing more interest in the "echils" \- food spilt down from our mouth.   
These are just tools for 'I' so that it can simply continue in the garb of  
spiritual enquiry and enjoy its existence. It does not at akk matter if  
awareness is watching awareness or awareness is not watching awareness,  
whether Ramana's teachings are same as Michal James or different, whether  
Bhakti yoga is same as Jnana Yoga or different. Whether my point is accepted  
here or rejected. whether the discussions is helping or not.   
'I' \- just hold on to it, everything else is play and only play: Merry-  
Go-Round   
Self Enquiry is like the passive observer. A classic example which Shankara  
Bhagavatpadal has given is that of the bird Dove which lays eggs and carefully  
guards it everyday and accumulates food for it from various places and when  
the eggs are going to hatch, one day the crow comes pushes the eggs down from  
the nest and eats all the eggs and just born dove. The dove, which comes there  
just sees all this without reaction. It just remains.   
Such should be our enquiry.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 27, 2010, 01:40:11 PM

Here is the classic pic taken from the famous movie Adi Shankaracharya. Its  
one of the best examples as to how our enquiry has to be carried on: Crow and dove.Crow is the doer, the active one.The dove is the passive  
observer, the atman(inner self) - our attention should be always focussed only  
on this.   
instead of focusing our attention on the 'I', if the Dove begins to fight with  
the crow, it is only going to cause damage and loss of peace. Just remaining  
indifferent to what is happening, remaining in the world, carrying out our  
duties, we should remain like the Dove with our attention focused on the Self  
till our Prarabhha karma is dissolved.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

Dear viswanathan   
I agree with your detailed clarfifcations on the points of Michael   
Langford 'Awareness Watching Awareness'. The problems in   
any translation of the original work are that one has to compromise   
with some loss of beauty and cadence. A friend of mine, long time   
back, went to study Russian, to read Leo Tolstoy's War and Peace   
in original. But most of us cannot do that way. Why? Even Tamizhians today  
cannot properly read and understand classical   
Tamizh works like Bhagavan's ULLadu Narpadu. The untranslatatbility of Tamizh  
is quite high. In Tamizh, one often goes even without a verb. Nan Yaar means  
only "I Who" and not   
"Who am I?" Hence many problems have to be confronted by the   
translators. So long as Langford clarifies Watching means Being,   
then, as I already wrote, there is no problem. Even in Sanskrit,   
sometimes the word Darshan means not seeing but being. Siva darshan sometimes  
means Being Siva or Being in Sivam.   
As regards methods, again since every marga leads one ultimately to the one  
marga of self attention, there is no quarrel, in that sense.   
I also refer to Michael James as you have mentioned. He is the guy who read  
and mastered Tamizh while simultaneously venturing understanding and  
practicing Bhagavan Ramana's methods. Hence his books and translations are  
really of a higher order. In his   
Happiness and the Art of Being, he refers to ULLadu Narpadu   
verses and he always gives in italics the Tamizh word or phrases and again and  
again use many ways to describe the purport.   
Arunachala Siva.

## Re:[36] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 28, 2010, 07:19:36 AM  
---  
Dear I,   
Quote from: viswanathan on June 28, 2010, 03:16:39 AM  
 I agree with your comments as above.When we know that who am I is simply holding on to the "I", why so many posts in this forum on various headings on various topics?. **Bhagavan has given his first teaching "Naan Yar' crystal clear without any room for doubt and still do we require endless discussions on his teachings ?** **It is enough if only Bhagavan 's teachings alone are published in this site as being done by Sri Subramanian and Mr.Prasanth (Both of them are doing great service) and there are sufficient material for them to publish more of Bhagaan's works for many years**.This will help members who have not so far gone thro his books and for the one who has already gone through, it will help to refresh.Few years back, Swami Chinmayananda was invited to a Ramana function and was asked to deliver his talk on Bhagavan Ramana.He did not deliver lecture and instead sat in silence forsome time and at the end told the audience that this is what bhagavan's teaching. **Bhagavan says that Silence is ever speaking and it is interrupted by speaking.Are we following his teachings?**  
You are absolutely correct. The best course is to simply maintain silence. I  
have always found the tamizh works of Ramana more clearer than any of the  
other languages, it may be because it is my mother tongue, but I did not know  
how to read or write tamizh, but due to Bhagavan's grace, I am learning to  
read and write tamizh now atleast I am able to read it slowly though.   
Personally, I feel, Bhagavan's teachings are to be discussed within the Self  
alone, in the course of enquiry itself and not outside. One has to taste the  
tea himself to know its taste, no matter what elaboration anybody gives, is  
going to be of no avail.   
It is due to the Vasana of finding out answers to our questions that breeds  
questions and endless discussions. Bhagavans says, we need not know any  
answers at all. We fail to recognise the very presence of Bhagavan Ramana, if  
he is not there physically, does it mean that he is not going to clear our  
questions within? its because of this wrong notion, that we begin to discuss  
our issues or questions and it leads to analyses over analyses. What we need  
is a strong belief or Faith or Shraddha that Bhagavan will clear all doubts  
Himself and I need not ask anybody and that He himself will reveal it to me in  
any way, maybe an unknown person would come and say something in some other  
context, or through some incidents. We just need to remain alive and keep the  
enquiry always going. Like how Dhathathreya had 24 Gurus, most of them being  
animals, in a similar way, Bhagavan will bestow on us the clarity in some way  
or the other.   
To ask doubts and discussing it is going outwards. We have to remain within  
our self - holding on just to 'I' alone.   
In Talks: 253: Bhagavan has said The illiterates are certainly better off than the  
literates whose egos are not destroyed by the quest of the self.   
355: "Illiteracy is ignorance: education is learned ignorance. Both of them  
are ignorant of their true aim; whereas a sage is not ignorant because there  
is no aim for him."   
D.: Mind itself is very subtle and is also the same as the Atman.   
How shall we know the nature of the mind? You have said that all   
supports are useless. What should be our stand then?   
M.: Where does your mind stand?   
D.: Where does it stand?   
M.: Ask the mind itself.   
D.: I ask you now. Should we concentrate on mind then?   
M.: Um!   
D.: But what is the nature of the mind? It is formless. The problem   
is perplexing.   
M.: Why are you perplexed?   
D.: The sastras want us to concentrate and I cannot do so.   
M.: Through what sastras have we known our existence?   
D.: It is a matter of experience. But I want to concentrate.   
M.: Be free from thoughts. Do not hold on to anything. They do not   
hold you. Be yourself.   
D.: I do not yet understand as to where I take my stand and concentrate.   
Can I meditate on my mind?   
M.: Whose mind?   
D.: My own mind?   
M.: Who are you? The question now resolves itself all right.   
(All retired for lunch. The visitor returned at 2-30 p.m. and pursued   
the same question.)   
He said: Maharshi advises the seeker to get rid of thoughts. On what   
should I concentrate the mind after all the thoughts are expelled? I   
do not see where I stand then and on what I should concentrate.   
M.: For whom is the concentration?   
D.: For the mind.   
M.: Then concentrate the mind.   
D.: On what?   
M.: Answer the question yourself. What is the mind? Why should   
you concentrate?   
D.: I do not know what the mind is. I ask Maharshi.   
M.: Maharshi does not seek to know the mind. The questioner must   
question the mind itself as to what it is.   
 **D.: Maharshi advises that the mind should be divested of thoughts.   
M.: This is itself a thought.**   
D.: When all thoughts disappear what remains over?   
M.: Is the mind different from thoughts?   
 **D.: No. The mind is made up of thoughts. My point is this: When all   
thoughts are got rid of, how shall I concentrate the mind?   
M.: Is not this also a thought?**   
D.: Yes, but I am advised to concentrate.   
M.: Why should you concentrate? Why should you not allow your   
thoughts free play?   
D.: The sastras say that the thoughts, thus playing free, lead us astray,   
that is, to unreal and changeful things.   
M.: So then, you want not to be led to unreal and changeful things. Your   
thoughts are unreal and changeful. You want to hold the Reality. That   
is exactly what I say. The thoughts are unreal. Get rid of them.   
 **D.: I understand now. Yet there is a doubt. Not a trice can you remain   
inactive. How shall I be able to rid myself of thoughts?   
M.: The same Gita says: Although all actions take place, I am not the doer.   
It is like the sun towards the world activities. The Self always remains   
actionless, whereas thoughts arise and subside. The Self is Perfection; it   
is immutable; the mind is limited and changeful. You need only to cast   
off your limitations. Your perfection thus stands revealed.**   
D.: Grace is necessary for it.   
 _ **M.: Grace is ever present. All that is necessary is that you surrender to  
It.**_   
D.: I surrender and pray that even if I go wrong I may be forcibly   
drawn to it.   
 **M.: Is this surrender? Surrender to be complete must be   
unquestioning.**   
D.: Yes, I surrender. You say I must dive into the ocean of the Self   
like a pearl-diver into the sea.   
M.: Because you are now thinking that you are out of the ocean of   
Consciousness.   
D.: I practise pranayama. It generates heat in the body. What should   
I do?   
M.: The heat will pass away when the mind gains calm   
D.: That is true but most difficult.   
 **M.: This is again a thought which is an obstacle.  
Salutations to Sri Ramana

The point is : mind cannot be killed, coz its never alive to be killed.   
like the snake on a rope. should the snake be killed?   
i am awareness, right now -- there is no choice here.   
and as awareness, i "CANNOT" get sad, happy or anything else. AS AWareness, i  
a Every STillness.   
so its not "Be Still" \-- u R STILLNESS. .. no choice here!   
so when someone says "I WILL BE STILL" thats foolish. As Awareness there is no  
choice. One is STILLNESS ITSELF.   
AS mind, one cannot remain still... coz mind by nature is unreal. mind cannot  
become SAT.   
So, here is the problem. People want the mind to be Still... body to stop  
growing!! how is it ever possible.   
body by its nature has to grow old. mind by its nature has to change. Self  
cannot Change.   
This is the essence.   
Swami Suddhananda gives a nice example: Someone was asked "What is ur age", he  
said "30". "But u said the same thing 10 years ago", asked another who was  
present there. "That is right, i tell the truth and truth cannot change", was  
his reply!   
what kind of truth is that??   
The attempt to stop the mirage like world from appearing is also a mistake.  
coz it shall continue as long as one's prarabdha is there unfinished. no one  
can stop it.   
Love!   
Silence

suppose i am watching a movie and have taken myself to be a character in it

the movie?   
is not the teaching in the movie too? is not the instruction "u r not this,  
but that which is outside", its for mind.   
Silence  
when the sage comes on the screen and says u are not this, you are not that  
and etc... and what ever you decide to do: 1 Stop the movie,   
2 continue the movie   
3 follow the sage   
4 not listen the sage   
5 do self enquiry   
6 letting the movie continue by allowing the assitant director to decide on  
the next scenarios believing that it cannot affect me, etc...   
these are still part of the movie itself. These are all the various courses  
the mind has, as options in the movie, as the director. These are "Freewill"  
which the i believes it has, which it can use to do what i wants to.   
Movie is in reality, not there at all, movie exist only for the mind alone  
which is non-self. In ignorance, the character itself, is the one which has  
created the movie and various scenarios and also the sage who comes and says  
you are not this you are that is just another character in the movie created  
by the mind again to make the movie more interesting, thats all.   
Once the character discards his dress knowing its limitedness - means there is  
no more i at all, no director at all, there is no more movie anymore. Movie  
existed only for the mithya i.   
The instruction "u r not this, but that which is outside", its for mind." is  
itself just Mithya as well. It is just a story in the movie, which the i gets  
identified with whereby 'i' mistakenly takes these instruction for itself and  
begins to enquire who am i, I am the Self, I am this and I am that. these are  
all again just illusions. There is no need for self enquiry as well.   
There is no movie at all.   
Appearance is only for the 'i' mind alone. as long as the mind exists  
appearances will continue, as appearances are all the creations of the mind  
alone. Where there are no appearances and where only  
awareness/consciousness/Self alone IS, is real. _Where appearances still are_  
, the sage asks him to enquire its nature.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

## Re:[45] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Subramanian.R       Date: June 28, 2010, 01:52:04 PM  
---  
Dear prasanth and others,   
The problem is that we are not able to visualize a state where the   
mind is killed. Mind-killing seems to be bothering most of us.   
If you substitute ego with mind, then, we are comfortable. Everyone   
agrees that one should kill the ego. Bhagavan Ramana also concludes   
ULLadu Narpadu by saying, Ahandhai uru azhitale mukti. The destruction of the  
ego is liberation. But Bhagavan Ramana uses   
the phrase mano-nasam in Who am I? He does not say Ahandai nasam. For that  
matter, He never uses the word Ahandai, ego   
in Who am I? directly. This is a poser for all of us! However, He gives one  
description about ahandai or ahankaram in Who am I? He says that "I-thought  
is the first thought from the mind. And this ahankaram."   
Arunachala Siva.

tamil this word commonly refers to saliva which we spit..Also, any food left  
over in the plate by the eater is also called "Echils" and is considered  
impure and and unhygienic for others to eat. The people who eat left over  
food(Echils)are looked down in society and also sometimes ridiculed..However,  
it is a a common sight in marriages that the food left over on the plate  
will be thrown in dust bin and will be collected by poorest of poor  
especially gypsies(Narikoravas) to satisfy their hunger.Also the left over  
food thrown in dust bin will be shared by dogs and other animals who are not  
fortunate as us.. In the orthodox brahmin families it is still a practice  
wherein the husband will eat first and the plate will not be washed and will  
have some left over food and in the same plate wife will be served food and  
here the "Echils" is very much nourished by the wife taken as prasad from  
husband and that "Echil" is not considered as unhygienic..However the same  
parent will not approve their children sharing "Echils".During Bhagavan days,  
some of orthodox devotees will wait till Bhagavan finishes eating and when he  
leaves dining hall, they will rush to collect the "Echil"(food left in  
hagavan's plate) and eat it as Bhagavan's prasad. When Bhagavan came to know  
of this practice, he did not approve of this.There was a well known saint by  
name Poondi Swamiyar wherein devotees will eat the food tasted by Poondi  
Swamiar and here "Echil" was very considered as divine and was very much  
respected.In swami suddhananda's ashram, Swami used to advice devotees in  
dining hall to leave some food("Echils") in plate for the animals in the  
ashram.   
During last days of Sri.Ramakrishna Paramahamsha, he was suffering with  
Cancer which was in advanced state.His closest aides who were were serving him  
were afraid to go near him fearing that they will also contract cancer and  
left him.On seeing this, Swami Vivekananda took a glass of liquid and gave it  
to Sri ramakrishna to drink and then Swami Vivekananda drank the left  
over(Echil) in the glass.On seeing this, Sri Ramakrishna's close aides got  
over the fear of Contracting Cancer and started serving him again.

## Re:[53] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 30, 2010, 06:47:40 AM  
---  
Dear I   
Quote from: srkudai on June 29, 2010, 07:54:26 AM  
When ego is burnt, still there is role playing, but one knows clearly that one  
is not ravana.   
why should an enlightened person not continue playing the role of Ravana,  
knowing pretty well that there is only Rama?   
Appearances are only projection of the mind, similarly, Ravana is a character  
projected by the mind. When the mind is merged into itself - Self, Ravana  
ceases to be, as there will be no mind for projection of Ravana.   
You have to remain as Rama (actually not even reamaing, you are 'that' Tat  
Tvam Asi), There is no way you can continue playing the role of Ravana, that  
implies that mind is still there.   
Once the mind is merged into Self, there will/should not be any appearances,  
i.e. no more any projections. There will only be Rama and Rama everywhere. No  
more roles, characters, etc...   
If it is so, that the Ravana role continues, and even if that role does not  
affect us as Rama, then still it is only projection of the Mind. Therefore  
Mind has still not merged.   
After enlightenment, realising that the cinema is not real, why do you still  
want to sit and watch the movie that is not there? movie still being continued  
- do you not think that still mind is there projecting the universe?   
Mind has to merge, this is Mano Naasam! which is - absolutely no projections  
at all and no continuing of movies or characters or is it even the  
enlightenment that the roles can continue and that it cannot affect you  
anymore.   
These are my humble views   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

Content:

## Re:[55] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 30, 2010, 07:06:12 AM  
---  
A Jeevan Muktha is said to have had release from body and still exist in the  
body for **outsiders** like ourselves. It is Videha muktha what you are  
talking about.   
In Sadashiva Brahmendral, we have seen how his hands were chopped off and yet  
he continued to walk without even being aware of it. We all know how Ramana  
Maharshi had his tumor operated without even taking anesthesia.   
It only appears for outsiders like ourselves that a Jivanmukta has prarabdha,  
that they have body, etc.., but they do not have any prarabdha or body.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

videha muktha is released from body. jeevan mukha has body.   
The jnani who said "I do not have body" is also appears to others only.   
When a person is in the influence of drugs u can try cutting off their body  
parts and they may move unconcerned.   
all these have happened in your view. in your peception.   
so lets speak from your perception.   
Does the jnani say u have a body? he says u too do not have a body. infact he  
says there is no u!   
and yet he is speaking. if u ask, the reply is "in ur view i am speaking to  
u".   
then how come u say a jeevan muktha has no body? No one has a body that way.   
so there is no projection even now!   
but u speak of ending a projection! which means u have already assumed there  
is a projection.   
if there is a projection, that is in ur view. then that projection ends after  
videha mukti. .. that too in your view.   
we can only speak from our standpoint. A Jeevan muktha has body and a Videha  
muktha has no body.

## Re:[57] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 30, 2010, 07:40:29 AM  
---  
Dear I,   
Every thing that is being discussed is only a 'stand point' of view, which is  
only the mind's. It can never know the consciousness which is unlimited.  
whatever we try and say is only making it limited.   
A Jivan Mukta does not have a body, as consciousness, 'it' is pervaded  
everywhere and everything. No one has body. since it is projection of mind, it  
exists as sanke in rope.   
In the end, you speak from your perception and I speak from my perception.   
There is no your perception and my perception. You are talking to yourself and  
I am talking to myself. There is no You and I.   
Perception exists only for the mind. Perception is again just a projection. as  
long as the Mind exists, perception, projection, etc.. continues. When, Mano  
Naasam, all is naught.   
The games of your perception, my perception etc.. continue for the mind, is it  
not the projection of the mind?   
Quote  
we can only speak from our standpoint. A Jeevan muktha has body and a Videha  
muktha has no body.  
That everything is only the projection of the mind including the Jivanmukta  
and Videhamukta. When Mano Naasam, there is no Jivanmukta, no Videhamukta, No  
consciousness, no nothing or there is Jivanmukta, there is Videhamukta,  
Consciousness everywhere, Aatman, Brahman.   
These are all again the projections of mind.   
This mind as to merge. this is Mano naasam. As long as there are projections  
of any type, mind has not merged.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

there are only two possibilities: A person with merged mind said this. which

a person whose mind is not merged is saying what will happen when mind merges.

both cases are meaningless.   
simple point... merging of mind is not absence of projection. its just veiling

final merging or elimination of projection is videha mukti. not jeevan mukthi.

## Re:[45] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Subramanian.R       Date: June 28, 2010, 01:52:04 PM  
---  
Dear prasanth and others,   
The problem is that we are not able to visualize a state where the   
mind is killed. Mind-killing seems to be bothering most of us.   
If you substitute ego with mind, then, we are comfortable. Everyone   
agrees that one should kill the ego. Bhagavan Ramana also concludes   
ULLadu Narpadu by saying, Ahandhai uru azhitale mukti. The destruction of the  
ego is liberation. But Bhagavan Ramana uses   
the phrase mano-nasam in Who am I? He does not say Ahandai nasam. For that  
matter, He never uses the word Ahandai, ego   
in Who am I? directly. This is a poser for all of us! However, He gives one  
description about ahandai or ahankaram in Who am I? He says that "I-thought  
is the first thought from the mind. And this ahankaram."   
Arunachala Siva.

## Re:[57] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 30, 2010, 07:40:29 AM  
---  
Dear I,   
Every thing that is being discussed is only a 'stand point' of view, which is  
only the mind's. It can never know the consciousness which is unlimited.  
whatever we try and say is only making it limited.   
A Jivan Mukta does not have a body, as consciousness, 'it' is pervaded  
everywhere and everything. No one has body. since it is projection of mind, it  
exists as sanke in rope.   
In the end, you speak from your perception and I speak from my perception.   
There is no your perception and my perception. You are talking to yourself and  
I am talking to myself. There is no You and I.   
Perception exists only for the mind. Perception is again just a projection. as  
long as the Mind exists, perception, projection, etc.. continues. When, Mano  
Naasam, all is naught.   
The games of your perception, my perception etc.. continue for the mind, is it  
not the projection of the mind?   
Quote  
we can only speak from our standpoint. A Jeevan muktha has body and a Videha  
muktha has no body.  
That everything is only the projection of the mind including the Jivanmukta  
and Videhamukta. When Mano Naasam, there is no Jivanmukta, no Videhamukta, No  
consciousness, no nothing or there is Jivanmukta, there is Videhamukta,  
Consciousness everywhere, Aatman, Brahman.   
These are all again the projections of mind.   
This mind as to merge. this is Mano naasam. As long as there are projections  
of any type, mind has not merged.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana
 ---  
Source:[http://web.archive.org/web/20100707035748/http://www.arunachala-ramana.org/forum/index.php?topic=5615.msg16211](http://web.archive.org/web/20100707035748/http://www.arunachala-ramana.org/forum/index.php?topic=5615.msg16211)   
---

## Re:[45] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Subramanian.R       Date: June 28, 2010, 01:52:04 PM  
---  
Dear prasanth and others,   
The problem is that we are not able to visualize a state where the   
mind is killed. Mind-killing seems to be bothering most of us.   
If you substitute ego with mind, then, we are comfortable. Everyone   
agrees that one should kill the ego. Bhagavan Ramana also concludes   
ULLadu Narpadu by saying, Ahandhai uru azhitale mukti. The destruction of the  
ego is liberation. But Bhagavan Ramana uses   
the phrase mano-nasam in Who am I? He does not say Ahandai nasam. For that  
matter, He never uses the word Ahandai, ego   
in Who am I? directly. This is a poser for all of us! However, He gives one  
description about ahandai or ahankaram in Who am I? He says that "I-thought  
is the first thought from the mind. And this ahankaram."   
Arunachala Siva.
 ---

## Re:[51] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: viswanathan         Date: June 29, 2010, 10:51:28 AM  
---  
Quote from: Nagaraj on June 27, 2010, 01:17:46 PM  
Who am I is simply holding on to the 'I'. All the analysis are to be given  
absolutely no importance at all. one need not even learn all these  
intricacies. After all what is the real objective? is not to hold on to the  
'I'? its like, we forget the main dishes served in an plantain leaf and  
showing more interest in the "echils" \- food spilt down from our mouth.   
In the above quote,Mr.Nagaraj has introduced the word "Echils"-food split down  
from the mouth and i thought share some good and ad aspects of "Echil".. In  
tamil this word commonly refers to saliva which we spit..Also, any food left  
over in the plate by the eater is also called "Echils" and is considered  
impure and and unhygienic for others to eat. The people who eat left over  
food(Echils)are looked down in society and also sometimes ridiculed..However,  
it is a a common sight in marriages that the food left over on the plate  
will be thrown in dust bin and will be collected by poorest of poor  
especially gypsies(Narikoravas) to satisfy their hunger.Also the left over  
food thrown in dust bin will be shared by dogs and other animals who are not  
fortunate as us.. In the orthodox brahmin families it is still a practice  
wherein the husband will eat first and the plate will not be washed and will  
have some left over food and in the same plate wife will be served food and  
here the "Echils" is very much nourished by the wife taken as prasad from  
husband and that "Echil" is not considered as unhygienic..However the same  
parent will not approve their children sharing "Echils".During Bhagavan days,  
some of orthodox devotees will wait till Bhagavan finishes eating and when he  
leaves dining hall, they will rush to collect the "Echil"(food left in  
hagavan's plate) and eat it as Bhagavan's prasad. When Bhagavan came to know  
of this practice, he did not approve of this.There was a well known saint by  
name Poondi Swamiyar wherein devotees will eat the food tasted by Poondi  
Swamiar and here "Echil" was very considered as divine and was very much  
respected.In swami suddhananda's ashram, Swami used to advice devotees in  
dining hall to leave some food("Echils") in plate for the animals in the  
ashram.   
During last days of Sri.Ramakrishna Paramahamsha, he was suffering with  
Cancer which was in advanced state.His closest aides who were were serving him  
were afraid to go near him fearing that they will also contract cancer and  
left him.On seeing this, Swami Vivekananda took a glass of liquid and gave it  
to Sri ramakrishna to drink and then Swami Vivekananda drank the left  
over(Echil) in the glass.On seeing this, Sri Ramakrishna's close aides got  
over the fear of Contracting Cancer and started serving him again.

## Re:[53] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 30, 2010, 06:47:40 AM  
---  
Dear I   
Quote from: srkudai on June 29, 2010, 07:54:26 AM  
When ego is burnt, still there is role playing, but one knows clearly that one  
is not ravana.   
why should an enlightened person not continue playing the role of Ravana,  
knowing pretty well that there is only Rama?   
Appearances are only projection of the mind, similarly, Ravana is a character  
projected by the mind. When the mind is merged into itself - Self, Ravana  
ceases to be, as there will be no mind for projection of Ravana.   
You have to remain as Rama (actually not even reamaing, you are 'that' Tat  
Tvam Asi), There is no way you can continue playing the role of Ravana, that  
implies that mind is still there.   
Once the mind is merged into Self, there will/should not be any appearances,  
i.e. no more any projections. There will only be Rama and Rama everywhere. No  
more roles, characters, etc...   
If it is so, that the Ravana role continues, and even if that role does not  
affect us as Rama, then still it is only projection of the Mind. Therefore  
Mind has still not merged.   
After enlightenment, realising that the cinema is not real, why do you still  
want to sit and watch the movie that is not there? movie still being continued  
- do you not think that still mind is there projecting the universe?   
Mind has to merge, this is Mano Naasam! which is - absolutely no projections  
at all and no continuing of movies or characters or is it even the  
enlightenment that the roles can continue and that it cannot affect you  
anymore.   
These are my humble views   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

## Re:[55] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 30, 2010, 07:06:12 AM  
---  
A Jeevan Muktha is said to have had release from body and still exist in the  
body for **outsiders** like ourselves. It is Videha muktha what you are  
talking about.   
In Sadashiva Brahmendral, we have seen how his hands were chopped off and yet  
he continued to walk without even being aware of it. We all know how Ramana  
Maharshi had his tumor operated without even taking anesthesia.   
It only appears for outsiders like ourselves that a Jivanmukta has prarabdha,  
that they have body, etc.., but they do not have any prarabdha or body.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

is the first thought from the mind. And this ahankaram."   
Arunachala Siva.

## Re:[51] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: viswanathan         Date: June 29, 2010, 10:51:28 AM  
---  
Quote from: Nagaraj on June 27, 2010, 01:17:46 PM  
Who am I is simply holding on to the 'I'. All the analysis are to be given  
absolutely no importance at all. one need not even learn all these  
intricacies. After all what is the real objective? is not to hold on to the  
'I'? its like, we forget the main dishes served in an plantain leaf and  
showing more interest in the "echils" \- food spilt down from our mouth.   
In the above quote,Mr.Nagaraj has introduced the word "Echils"-food split down  
from the mouth and i thought share some good and ad aspects of "Echil".. In  
tamil this word commonly refers to saliva which we spit..Also, any food left  
over in the plate by the eater is also called "Echils" and is considered  
impure and and unhygienic for others to eat. The people who eat left over  
food(Echils)are looked down in society and also sometimes ridiculed..However,  
it is a a common sight in marriages that the food left over on the plate  
will be thrown in dust bin and will be collected by poorest of poor  
especially gypsies(Narikoravas) to satisfy their hunger.Also the left over  
food thrown in dust bin will be shared by dogs and other animals who are not  
fortunate as us.. In the orthodox brahmin families it is still a practice  
wherein the husband will eat first and the plate will not be washed and will  
have some left over food and in the same plate wife will be served food and  
here the "Echils" is very much nourished by the wife taken as prasad from  
husband and that "Echil" is not considered as unhygienic..However the same  
parent will not approve their children sharing "Echils".During Bhagavan days,  
some of orthodox devotees will wait till Bhagavan finishes eating and when he  
leaves dining hall, they will rush to collect the "Echil"(food left in  
hagavan's plate) and eat it as Bhagavan's prasad. When Bhagavan came to know  
of this practice, he did not approve of this.There was a well known saint by  
name Poondi Swamiyar wherein devotees will eat the food tasted by Poondi  
Swamiar and here "Echil" was very considered as divine and was very much  
respected.In swami suddhananda's ashram, Swami used to advice devotees in  
dining hall to leave some food("Echils") in plate for the animals in the  
ashram.   
During last days of Sri.Ramakrishna Paramahamsha, he was suffering with  
Cancer which was in advanced state.His closest aides who were were serving him  
were afraid to go near him fearing that they will also contract cancer and  
left him.On seeing this, Swami Vivekananda took a glass of liquid and gave it  
to Sri ramakrishna to drink and then Swami Vivekananda drank the left  
over(Echil) in the glass.On seeing this, Sri Ramakrishna's close aides got  
over the fear of Contracting Cancer and started serving him again.

## Re:[53] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 30, 2010, 06:47:40 AM  
---  
Dear I   
Quote from: srkudai on June 29, 2010, 07:54:26 AM  
When ego is burnt, still there is role playing, but one knows clearly that one  
is not ravana.   
why should an enlightened person not continue playing the role of Ravana,  
knowing pretty well that there is only Rama?   
Appearances are only projection of the mind, similarly, Ravana is a character  
projected by the mind. When the mind is merged into itself - Self, Ravana  
ceases to be, as there will be no mind for projection of Ravana.   
You have to remain as Rama (actually not even reamaing, you are 'that' Tat  
Tvam Asi), There is no way you can continue playing the role of Ravana, that  
implies that mind is still there.   
Once the mind is merged into Self, there will/should not be any appearances,  
i.e. no more any projections. There will only be Rama and Rama everywhere. No  
more roles, characters, etc...   
If it is so, that the Ravana role continues, and even if that role does not  
affect us as Rama, then still it is only projection of the Mind. Therefore  
Mind has still not merged.   
After enlightenment, realising that the cinema is not real, why do you still  
want to sit and watch the movie that is not there? movie still being continued  
- do you not think that still mind is there projecting the universe?   
Mind has to merge, this is Mano Naasam! which is - absolutely no projections  
at all and no continuing of movies or characters or is it even the  
enlightenment that the roles can continue and that it cannot affect you  
anymore.   
These are my humble views   
Salutations to Sri Ramana

## Re:[55] Is 'Awareness Watching Awareness'-method same as Sri Bhagavan's Self- Attention?  
Author: Nagaraj             Date: June 30, 2010, 07:06:12 AM  
---  
A Jeevan Muktha is said to have had release from body and still exist in the  
body for **outsiders** like ourselves. It is Videha muktha what you are  
talking about.   
In Sadashiva Brahmendral, we have seen how his hands were chopped off and yet  
he continued to walk without even being aware of it. We all know how Ramana  
Maharshi had his tumor operated without even taking anesthesia.   
It only appears for outsiders like ourselves that a Jivanmukta has prarabdha,  
that they have body, etc.., but they do not have any prarabdha or body.   
Salutations to Sri Ramana
